data.title: McRae, Alexander Duncan (1874-1946)
data.meta_description: Senator McRae, Winnipeg Tribune, June 27, 1946, page 9. Henderson’s City of Vancouver and North Vancouver Directory, 1910, Part 2, page 902. Henderson’s City of Vancouver and North Vancouver Directory, 1910, Part 1, page 731. Alexander Duncan McRae was the manager of Fraser River Lumber Company. He lived at 1960 Robson Street in 1910. (The…
data.text:
Alexander Duncan McRae was the manager of Fraser River Lumber Company. He lived at 1960 Robson Street in 1910. (The 1910 Vancouver directory spelled his name as McCrae.)

Family Background

Alexander Duncan McRae was born in Glencoe, Ontario on November 17, 1874. His parents were Duncan Alexander McRae (1833-1906) and Mary McWhinney (1845–1930).

Duncan McRae died in Glencoe, Ontario on February 11, 1906.

Mary McRae died in Glencoe on March 30, 1930.

Early Years

In August 1891, Alexander went to the United States. He worked with his cousins, Alexander and Andrew Davidson, who were based in Duluth, Minnesota.

Alexander started a firm that insured grain elevators. His investments were successful, and he became increasingly wealthy.

On August 15, 1898, he became a naturalized United States citizen.

Marriage to Blaunche Howe

On February 23, 1900, in Minneapolis, Minnesota, Alexander married Blaunche Latimer Howe. She was born in Millerstown, Pennsylvania on August 3, 1877. Her parents were George Coleman Howe (1851-1922) and Mary Elizabeth Johnston (1850-1934).

George Coleman Howe was a prominent businessman who had become wealthy through mining, oil, forestry, milling and other business investments. He died in Minneapolis on July 17, 1922.

Mary Elizabeth Howe died in Vancouver on May 15, 1934.

Real Estate Investments in Western Canada

In the early 1900s, Alexander and the Davidson brothers expanded their activities into the Canadian prairies, especially the Saskatchewan Valley Land Company and the Saskatchewan Valley and Manitoba Land Company. These enterprises, along with other associated businesses, acquired rights to sell vast amounts of Canadian prairie land from the federal government and from railway companies that were active in the area.

These companies encouraged settlement in the area, and they produced significant profits for Alexander and the other investors.

Alexander and his family appeared in the 1905 Minnesota census.

They were in Winnipeg, Manitoba at the time of the 1906 Canadian prairies census.

Arrival in British Columbia

While he was in Winnipeg, Alexander began investing in British Columbia, including fishing and logging businesses.

In 1910, he was involved with the Canadian Western Lumber Company, which took over further extensive timber interests.

He became the president of the Fraser River Lumber Company.

In 1912, the Victoria Daily Colonist published a long article that reviewed the Canadian Western Lumber Company’s operations in British Columbia.

Alexander lived at the following addresses in Vancouver.

In June 1910, the McRaes moved to 804 Nicola Street.

Soon after the McRaes arrived in Vancouver, Alexander acquired a large lot in Shaughnessy Heights, where he built a large house called Hycroft. Thomas Hooper was the architect.

The 30-room house became a centre of many society events in Vancouver.

War Service

During the First World War, Alexander became an officer in Canadian military forces. He went overseas with the Second Division of the Canadian Expeditionary Force, and he served in a variety of high-level military positions. In 1917 he became a Commander of the Bath (Military Division).

Political Activities and Later Life

After the war, Alexander became interested in politics. He became a member of the federal Parliament in 1926. In 1930 he was the organizer of the Conservative Party. In 1931 he became a senator.

During the 1930s, the McRaes built a large log house at Qualicum, on Vancouver Island, called Eaglecrest Lodge.

Blaunche McRae died in her suite at the Hotel Vancouver on November 10, 1942.

Blaunche’s funeral was held at Hycroft. She was buried in Ocean View Burial Park in Burnaby, British Columbia.

Alexander presented Hycroft to the federal government for use as an auxiliary military hospital. In December 1942, Hycroft’s contents went up for sale at auction. (Charles Edward Dawson (1881-1946) conducted the sale.) In 1962, the house became the home of the University Women’s Club of Vancouver.

Marriage to Louise Rodes and Final Years

On October 10, 1943, in New York, Alexander married Louise Rodes, who was born Louise Cain in 1890. She had been married earlier to Allen Higgins Rodes (1884-1927).

Alexander died in Ottawa, Ontario on June 26, 1946. He was buried in Ocean View Burial Park in Burnaby.

Louise later lived in Lexington, Kentucky.

Louise died in Lexington on May 16, 1961. She was buried in Lexington Cemetery.

Alexander and Blaunche had the following children.

Blanche Howe McRae

Blanche Howe McRae was born on March 12, 1904.

On July 26, 1922, in Minneapolis, Minnesota, Blanche married Richard Plunkett Baker. He was born in Donald, British Columbia, on October 18, 1888. His parents were Frederick Francis Baker (1858-1925) and Lucilla Ismina Cooke (1858-1925).

Richard had served with the Royal Air Force during the First World War. While he was in a battle with Manfred von Richthofen, the “Red Baron,” Richard managed to land his airplane, but German soldiers captured him and made him a prisoner of war. After the war he had returned to Vancouver, where he had an importing and exporting business.

In 1924, Janet Smith, a nursemaid for Richard’s niece, died in mysterious circumstances in Richard’s and Blanche’s house in Shaughnessy Heights. The reason for Janet Smith’s death remained a mystery. After a long and sensational trial, there was no criminal conviction and the case remained officially unsolved.

Richard’s aunt, Lily Lefevre, died in 1938, and Richard and Blanche moved into Lily’s large house on Point Grey Road.

However, Blanche later divorced Richard. (Richard became the manager of the Medical Dental Building in Vancouver, and later moved to Qualicum Beach. Richard died in Vancouver on April 1, 1954. He was buried in Qualicum Beach Cemetery.)

On September 30, 1944; Blanche married Daniel Beynon Lewis in Vancouver. Blanche died in Victoria, British Columbia, on August 31, 1945.

Daniel died in New Westminster, British Columbia on October 19, 1990.

Lucile Coleman McRae

Lucile Coleman McRae was born on May 3, 1905 (probably in Duluth, Minnesota, although some sources say she was born in Massachusetts).

She became engaged to Dwight C. Paul.

The marriage was in King County, Washington, on May 31, 1924.

This marriage ended in divorce. Dwight died in February 1968.

Lucile later married Gordon Howard Willard (sometimes known as “Howard Gordon Willard”).

Lucile died in Vancouver on August 29, 1955. She was buried in Ocean View Burial Park in Burnaby, British Columbia.

Gordon Willard died in Vancouver on December 9, 1966.

Dwight Paul and Lucile had a daughter, Blanche Beverly (“Bebe”) Paul (1925-1991).

Margaret (“Peggy”) McRae

Margaret (“Peggy”) McRae was born on January 30, 1906 in Winnipeg, Manitoba.

She studied at Northrop Collegiate school in Minneapolis, Minnesota.

On February 15, 1926, in Vancouver, she married Walter Seligman, who was a banker.

Walter was born in New York City on February 28, 1894. His parents were David Seligman and Adelaide Walter, who were married in New York in 1878.

David Seligman died in August 1897.

Adelaide later married Henry Seligman, who was David Seligman’s brother.

Henry Seligman died in 1933. Adelaide Seligman died in 1934.

Walter and Peggy were divorced. Walter died in Jacksonville, Florida on February 3, 1976.

On March 20, 1946, in Los Angeles County, California, Peggy married Richard Bruce Hay Chapman, who was in the insurance business. He was born in Los Angeles on March 20, 1897. His parents were Richard Henry Hay Chapman and Laura Lorimer.

Richard died in Santa Barbara, California on February 12, 1971.

Peggy died in San Francisco, California on November 19, 1972.

The 1901 Seligman Mansion — No. 30 West 56th St.; Daytonian in Manhattan; http://daytoninmanhattan.blogspot.com/2013/07/the-1901-seligman-mansion-no-30-west.html.

The Henry Seligman Residence, Beyond the Gilded Age, http://www.beyondthegildedage.com/2011/12/henry-seligman-residence.html.

Streetscapes/The Seligman Mansion, 30 East 56th Street; The Buyer Hopes to Reverse ‘Eat Street’s’ Decline, By Christopher Gray; New York Times, August 28, 1994, [Page 9009005 of the National edition]; https://www.nytimes.com/1994/08/28/realestate/streetscapes-seligman-mansion-30-east-56th-street-buyer-hopes-reverse-eat-street.html: “In 1899, at age 42, [Henry] Seligman married Addie Walter Seligman, the widow of his first cousin David, who had also been with the family firm. The newlyweds’ six-story, 20,000-square-foot building was finished in 1902; it was the widest house on West 56th Street, and mixed English and French elements with a limestone front and mansard roof.”
